loud 0.0.0.9000

    Advanced topics Introduction A real world example

    Introduction

    introduction.Rmd

    This package provides two functions, loudly() and bind_loudly() which can be used to add logging to any function. First, using loudly() you create a new function:

    library(loud)
#> Loading required package: rlang

loud_sqrt <- loudly(sqrt)

    loud_sqrt() is a function, which you can apply to any input you would use on sqrt():

    
my_result <- loud_sqrt(1:5)

    Let’s check the contents of my_result:

    str(my_result)
#> List of 2
#>  $ result: num [1:5] 1 1.41 1.73 2 2.24
#>  $ log   : chr [1:2] "Log start..." "sqrt(1:5) started at 2022-02-18 20:44:00 and ended at 2022-02-18 20:44:00"

    As you can see, my_result is a list of two elements; $result, which contains the result of sqrt(1:5) and $log, which contains a simple log message.

    A problem that now arises, is that chained operations like this one:

    1:10 |>
  sqrt() |>
  exp() |>
  mean()
#> [1] 11.55345

    are not possible anymore. This is because loud_sqrt() returns a list, and loud_exp() expects a number, or an atomic vector of numbers. In order to use chained operations, bind_loudly() must be used:

    loud_sqrt <- loudly(sqrt)
loud_exp <- loudly(exp)
loud_mean <- loudly(mean)

1:10 |>
  loud_sqrt() |>
  bind_loudly(loud_exp) |>
  bind_loudly(loud_mean)
#> $result
#> [1] 11.55345
#> 
#> $log
#> [1] "Log start..."                                                                   
#> [2] "sqrt(1:10) started at 2022-02-18 20:44:01 and ended at 2022-02-18 20:44:01"     
#> [3] "exp(.l$result) started at 2022-02-18 20:44:01 and ended at 2022-02-18 20:44:01" 
#> [4] "mean(.l$result) started at 2022-02-18 20:44:01 and ended at 2022-02-18 20:44:01"

    If you prefer using pipes instead of bind_loudly(), this package also provides a pipe operator, but be careful, this infix operator has not been tested properly and I don’t trust that it works, and neither should you:

    
1:10 |>
  loud_sqrt() %>=%
  loud_exp() %>=%
  loud_mean()
#> $result
#> [1] 11.55345
#> 
#> $log
#> [1] "Log start..."                                                                   
#> [2] "sqrt(1:10) started at 2022-02-18 20:44:01 and ended at 2022-02-18 20:44:01"     
#> [3] "exp(.l$result) started at 2022-02-18 20:44:01 and ended at 2022-02-18 20:44:01" 
#> [4] "mean(.l$result) started at 2022-02-18 20:44:01 and ended at 2022-02-18 20:44:01"

    However this implies mixing pipes and ideally, configuring a keyboard shortcut to easily input %>=%.

    If you want to retrieve any element from the final operation, you can do so with pick():

    1:10 |>
  loud_sqrt() |>
  bind_loudly(loud_exp) |>
  bind_loudly(loud_mean) |>
  pick("result")
#> [1] 11.55345
    
1:10 |>
  loud_sqrt() %>=%
  loud_exp() %>=%
  loud_mean() |>
  pick("log")
#> [1] "Log start..."                                                                   
#> [2] "sqrt(1:10) started at 2022-02-18 20:44:01 and ended at 2022-02-18 20:44:01"     
#> [3] "exp(.l$result) started at 2022-02-18 20:44:01 and ended at 2022-02-18 20:44:01" 
#> [4] "mean(.l$result) started at 2022-02-18 20:44:01 and ended at 2022-02-18 20:44:01"

    or you could use the pluck() function from the purrr package:

    1:10 |>
  loud_sqrt() |>
  bind_loudly(loud_exp) |>
  bind_loudly(loud_mean) |>
  purrr::pluck("log")
#> [1] "Log start..."                                                                   
#> [2] "sqrt(1:10) started at 2022-02-18 20:44:01 and ended at 2022-02-18 20:44:01"     
#> [3] "exp(.l$result) started at 2022-02-18 20:44:01 and ended at 2022-02-18 20:44:01" 
#> [4] "mean(.l$result) started at 2022-02-18 20:44:01 and ended at 2022-02-18 20:44:01"
